user.biography: The most powerful stories from human history.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered on September 15, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, child, people standing and outdoors.

node.text:
Before she became Barack Obama's mother at the age of 18, Ann Dunham was a high school student described by her friends as "intellectually way more mature than we were and a little bit ahead of her time, in an off-center way" and "the original feminist." Dunham was twice married by the time she was 23, but she never let her personal life get in the way of her career as an anthropologist. She moved from Honolulu to Jakarta in 1967 — bringing along a six-year-old Barack Obama — and she began what would become a lifelong study of rural blacksmithing traditions in Indonesia. ⁠
⁠
Thanks to her groundbreaking work in the developing world, she was able to show that much of the rural poverty in the region was due to a lack of resources, rather than cultural differences with the West, which was the prevailing theory at the time. And at one point, she pioneered a microfinance system that focused on providing savings and a small amount of credit to rural women that eventually grew into the largest system of its kind in the world. ⁠
⁠
Click the link in our profile to read more about the extraordinary life of Barack Obama's mother — and how she influenced her son.⁠
⁠
⁠
#barackobamasmom #anndunham #ushistory #uspresidents #obama #anthropology

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered on September 15, 2021. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text:
When Fanny Mills emigrated from England to Sandusky, Ohio in the 1860s, she was a petite teenager of only 115 pounds — but she carried most of that weight in her legs and feet. Mills was a victim of Milroy's disease, which caused her lower legs and feet to swell with lymphatic fluid. Her feet grew to a whopping 19 inches long, forcing her to wear shoes made of three goatskins and to use pillowcases for socks.⁠
⁠
But by the 1880s, people with abnormalities like hers could often find work and even fame, as long as they were willing to debase themselves before paying audiences on the “freak show” circuit. Click the link in our profile to go inside the strange, sad story of Fanny Mills, the "Ohio Big Foot Girl".⁠
⁠
⁠
#fannymills #ohiobigfootgirl #freakshow #historyuncovered #ushistory

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered in Canada. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'TRUE CRIME Karla Homolka Helped Rape And Kill Her Own S”s Today, She Walks Free In Canada'.

node.text:
Between 1990 and 1992, sadistic 20-somethings Karla Homolka and her husband Paul Bernardo raped, tortured, and murdered multiple young women in Ontario, Canada. Known together as the Barbie and Ken killers, the vicious couple even dismembered and encased one 14-year-old victim in cement in 1991. Though both were caught and imprisoned, Homolka received what many believed was a shockingly lenient sentence — and was released in just 12 years. Today, she volunteers at her children's elementary school.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our profile to go inside the disturbing story of Karla Homolka, the sadistic woman who helped her husband brutalize teenage girls — including her own sister.⁠
⁠
⁠
#karlahomolka #kenandbarbiekillers #disturbing #serialkillers #paulbernardo

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered on September 15, 2021. May be an image of 2 people and people standing.

node.text:
Known as "incandescent evil" and "a new strain of son of a bitch," Roy Cohn was a notorious Washington fixer who aggressively pushed McCarthy's Red Scare and outed closeted government officials — despite being gay himself. And before his AIDS-related death in 1986, he taught Donald Trump everything he knew.⁠
⁠
The two met in a New York City nightclub when Trump was in his 20s. While discussing impending lawsuits for discriminatory housing practices, the future president said, "I've followed your career and you seem — you’re a little bit crazy like I am, and you stand up to the establishment. Can I come see you?"⁠
⁠
Learn more about the cruel, moralless methods of Roy Cohn by clicking the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
⁠
⁠
#roycohn #donaldtrump #redscare #aids

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered in Auschwitz. May be an image of 9 people, people standing and outdoors.

node.text:
In 2007, a Nazi officer's secret photo album came to light and revealed the gleeful private lives of the SS guards who worked inside Auschwitz, the deadliest extermination camp of the Holocaust.⁠
⁠
Many of the photos were taken at Solahütte, a secret SS resort where death camp guards who "performed their work at Auschwitz in an exemplary fashion" could take a vacation. Follow the link in our profile the good times that Auschwitz guards enjoyed while more than a million prisoners were being killed at the camp.⁠
⁠
⁠
⁠
#haunting #unsettling #historyphotos #worldwar2 #auschwitz

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered on September 14, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Al Capone's Granddaughters Just Put 174 OfHis Personal Items Up For Sale Including His Favorite Gun'.

node.text:
Al Capone spent his final days in 1947 in a syphilitic fever, ranting at imaginary guests at his Florida mansion. And when he died, he left behind a hoard of personal items that his only child, Sonny, held onto for his entire life. When Sonny died in 2004, the heirlooms passed on to his three daughters.⁠
⁠
Now in their 70s, Al Capone's granddaughters are putting those cherished heirlooms up for auction at a private club in Sacramento, California. Only 200 invited guests will be able to participate in the bidding, which is expected to net upwards of $700,000. Items for sale range from household porcelain trinkets and personal letters from Capone to jewelry monogrammed with single-cut diamonds and even Capone's "favorite" Colt .45. Learn more about this exclusive auction for Al Capone's estate by visiting the link in our profile.⁠
⁠
⁠
#alcapone #gangsters #famouspeople #historynews #auctions

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered on September 14, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, people standing and outdoors.

node.text:
The Nazis nicknamed these female Soviet pilots the Nachthexen, or the "Night Witches," because the sound their planes made reminded them of a sweeping broom. And that noise was the only warning the Germans had before the pilots dropped bombs on them.⁠
⁠
"The planes were too small to show up on radar," an expert explained. "They never used radios, so radio locators couldn't pick them up either. They were basically ghosts." Completing 30,000 bombing raids over four years, the Night Witches were so successful that the Germans were convinced they'd been given injections that allowed them to see in the dark.⁠
⁠
Discover their incredible true story by visiting the link in our profile.⁠
⁠
⁠
#nightwitches #bombers #sovietunion #worldwar2 #ww2 #redarmy #militaryhistory

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered on September 14, 2021. May be an illustration.

node.text:
A 2013 police raid in Brazil turned up thousands of plundered fossils just before they were due to be shipped out of the country and likely lost to science forever. Now, researchers have confirmed that among them was the most intact skeleton of a rare pterosaur species ever found. Known as Tupandactylus navigans, this ancient flying reptile lived 100 million years ago and had a giant crest on the top of its head that accounted for more than 40 percent of its overall body height. Scientists think the crest prevented it from flying long distances — but likely served a purpose to attract mates.⁠
⁠
Learn more about this remarkable discovery by visiting the link in our profile.⁠
⁠
⁠
#fossils #dinosaurs #pterosaur #flyingreptile #prehistoric #tupandactylusnavigans

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered in Iran. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text:
"I couldn't continue like this. I knew I could get the operation easily enough in London, but I wanted the documentation so I could live."⁠
⁠
In the 1970s, Maryam Khatoon Molkara was using her connections among Iran's clerics and government authorities to lobby for an official authorization for transgender people like herself to undergo gender reassignment surgery without fear of persecution.⁠
⁠
Molkara's struggle and ongoing persistence for that right have since transformed Iran into one of the most open-minded Middle Eastern nations on transgender rights. Click the link in our bio to learn how she was able to secure a fatwa to officially support transition surgery.⁠
⁠
⁠
⁠
#maryamkhatoonmolkara #transgender #transrights #iran #lgbtq #lgbtqhistory

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered in Inyo Mountains. May be an image of mountain.

node.text:
"There's a story that 30 miners got trapped in one of the mines underneath the building I live in. As grim as it is, they're still down there."⁠
⁠
In 2018, Texas entrepreneur Brent Underwood purchased an abandoned mining town in California's Inyo Mountains for $1.4 million. He embarked on a mission to restore the town but became snowed in. The 300-acre property is not only 25 miles from the nearest town but is built on a sordid history of violence. At one point, the boomtown experienced one murder per week — and Underwood has confirmed eerie happenings all throughout the town's remaining 22 buildings.⁠
⁠
Explore the storied ghost town by visiting the link in our profile.⁠
⁠
⁠
#inyomountains #americanfrontier #california #ushistory #ghosttown #abandonedplaces

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered in Scotland. May be an image of 16 people, child and people standing.

node.text:
Shortly after 9:30 AM on March 13, 1996, 43-year-old Thomas Hamilton walked into Dunblane Primary School in Scotland with four handguns and 743 rounds of ammunition. He then approached the gymnasium, where first-grade teacher Gwen Hogan was readying her 28 pupils for class. Over the next four minutes, Hamilton fired more than 100 shots that left Hogan and 16 of her young students dead. Then, the gunman shot himself, too.⁠
⁠
It was the deadliest school shooting in the history of the U.K. But it was also the last. By the end of 1997, the nation had all but banned private handgun ownership. Click the link in our profile to go inside the horrific mass shooting that changed the U.K.’s gun laws forever.⁠
⁠
⁠
#dunblanemassacre #dunblaneprimaryschool #disturbing #scotland

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered in Dieppe, France.

node.text:
"The battle of D-Day was won on the beaches of Dieppe."⁠
⁠
Two years before D-Day, Canadian and British troops launched an invasion of France at the German-occupied port of Dieppe. It ended in catastrophe after less than nine hours. Of the roughly 5,000 Canadian troops who invaded, some 3,300 were killed, wounded, or captured. The Allies didn’t account for the rocky beach terrain, which left their tanks stuck like sitting ducks. Meanwhile, one group of commandos accidentally landed early after being chased by a German boat. Another flanking group landed 15 minutes late, and the last group, which was supposed to distract the Nazis for the main invasion of ground troops, arrived a full half-hour behind schedule.⁠
⁠
But despite their losses, the Allies learned hard-won lessons that allowed for the successful invasion of Normandy in 1944. Visit the link in our profile to learn story of the disastrous invasion that paved the way for the Allied victory on D-Day.⁠
⁠
⁠
#diepperaid #france #worldwar2 #ww2battles #battles #militaryhistory
